Ron -

I do remember meeting in San Antonio.  About the location of Python =
- 
if you define environment variable PYTHON_CMD to be the actual full 
pat=
h of the Python interpreter (e.g. D:/PY234/PYTHON.EXE) then Cantera 
should=
 find Python there.  If this doesn't work, let me know. I'm not 
sure but y=
ou may need to define this with forward slashes as shown 
here, rather than=
 backslashes as is usual for Windows paths. Note that 
this wasn't working =
correctly in version 1.5.3 - it always used the 
hard-wired path C:/PYTHON2=
3/PYTHON.EXE without checking PYTHON_CMD. But 
this should be fixed in 1.5.=
4.

Dave



On Jun 22, 2004, at 5:50 AM, Ron Besser wrote:

> David,
> Than=
ks for the help--the binary windows install works. I spent a 
> couple of h=
ours on a flight getting it to go. It seems as if there is 
> a small bug i=
n that cantera expects Python to be at C:\Python23\python 
> no matter what=
 path you use. I tried to have it on D:, but it would 
> never work. But, I=
 just finally put Python on C: and it now works 
> fine. Now, I'll be doing=
 tutorials on the return flight! Thanks again. 
> By the way, we met at the=
 ECS conference in San Antonio after I gave a 
> talk showing the Chemkin m=
echanism for preferential oxidation of CO.
> Thanks,
> Ron Besser

 Goodwin <dgoodwin@...> wrote:

ng to do is just use the binary installer for

antera154.msi. This will install
>  everything you need to use Cantera from=
 Python or Matlab.
> Then you don't even have to have cygwin, or bother wit=
h running
>  'configure' etc.
>
> But to answer your question - it seems yo=
u have an incomplete

en 'ls' doesn't
>  work.
>
> Dave

Ron - 


I do remember meeting in San Antonio.  About the location of Pytho=
n -
if you define environment variable PYTHON_CMD to be the actual full
pat=
h of the Python interpreter (e.g. D:/PY234/PYTHON.EXE) then Cantera
should =
find Python there.  If this doesn't work, let me know. I'm not
sure but you=
 may need to define this with forward slashes as shown
here, rather than ba=
ckslashes as is usual for Windows paths. Note that
this wasn't working corr=
ectly in version 1.5.3 - it always used the
hard-wired path C:/PYTHON23/PYT=
HON.EXE without checking PYTHON_CMD.
But this should be fixed in 1.5.4.


D=
ave




On Jun 22, 2004, at 5:50 AM, Ron Besser wrote:


<excerpt>David,

T=
hanks for the help--the binary windows install works. I spent a
couple of h=
ours on a flight getting it to go. It seems as if there is
a small bug in t=
hat cantera expects Python to be at C:\Python23\python
no matter what path =
you use. I tried to have it on D:, but it would
never work. But, I just fin=
ally put Python on C: and it now works
fine. Now, I'll be doing tutorials o=
n the return flight! Thanks again.
By the way, we met at the ECS conference=
 in San Antonio after I gave a
talk showing the Chemkin mechanism for prefe=
rential oxidation of CO.

Thanks,

Ron Besser


<bold><italic>David Goodwin=

<<<color><param>0000,0000,EEEE</param>dgoodwin@...</color>></itali=
c></bold>
wrote:

Ron,


In that case the best thing to do is just use the =
binary installer for 

Windows. Download and run Cantera154.msi. This will =
install

 everything you need to use Cantera from Python or Matlab.

Then y=
ou don't even have to have cygwin, or bother with running

 'configure' etc=
.


But to answer your question - it seems you have an incomplete

 install=
ation of cygwin, or some path problem, if even 'ls' doesn't

 work.


Dave
=
